```

Thanks for reviewing Prince. I have a couple more nits to fix before making this Public. I'll resolve your suggestions before making the PR ready for review.

My current plan is along the lines of:
1) Move functions used across multiple files in xcvrd to common module (this PR)
2) Move the entire CMIS class into its own class in /cmis/cmis_manager_task.py similar to dom
3) Individual PRs to create separate functions for CMIS stage handling
4) Any additional cleanup ( remove _wrapper functions, rename util directory, other feedback etc )

would it make more sense to do this via a config file like was done for sensormond? https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-platform-daemons/blob/master/sonic-sensormond/scripts/sensormond#L485

> would it make more sense to do this via a config file like was done for sensormond? https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-platform-daemons/blob/master/sonic-sensormond/scripts/sensormond#L485

Hi Gregory,

We currently have the config set by the existing pmon_daemon_control.json config file:
https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Asonic-net%2Fsonic-buildimage+path%3Apmon_daemon_control.json&type=code

Example usage of this new config:
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/blob/30d2b7881971ad38fdc0b242f57c9efdb6f93693/device/nexthop/common/pmon_daemon_control.json#L5-L8

PR which adds new config flags to thermalctld:
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-platform-daemons/pull/635

PR which sets new config flags using  pmon_daemon_control.json:
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/23139/files

When we were working on this initially we thought pmon_daemon_control.json would be the most fitting place to put the configuration.

We hadn't seen your change to use platform_env.conf yet.

What are your thoughts on platform_env.conf vs pmon_daemon_control.json?

> > would it make more sense to do this via a config file like was done for sensormond? https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-platform-daemons/blob/master/sonic-sensormond/scripts/sensormond#L485
> 
> Hi Gregory,
> 
> We currently have the config set by the existing pmon_daemon_control.json config file: https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Asonic-net%2Fsonic-buildimage+path%3Apmon_daemon_control.json&type=code
> 
> Example usage of this new config: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/blob/30d2b7881971ad38fdc0b242f57c9efdb6f93693/device/nexthop/common/pmon_daemon_control.json#L5-L8
> 
> PR which adds new config flags to thermalctld: #635
> 
> PR which sets new config flags using pmon_daemon_control.json: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/23139/files
> 
> When we were working on this initially we thought pmon_daemon_control.json would be the most fitting place to put the configuration.
> 
> We hadn't seen your change to use platform_env.conf yet.
> 
> What are your thoughts on platform_env.conf vs pmon_daemon_control.json?

I had actually originally tried the same thing using the pmon daemon control to act as a further input for this to the supervisord configuration: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-platform-daemons/pull/600/commits/9e917891794e1b2d3ec502e287b79b280947d6ea#diff-195551a342dbd08efef0aa4f3e21a4f4e24e2ee87cadcc27070299e9fc4a0390R560. General community sentiment though was to use the platform_env.conf for platform specific configurability (at least when this was discussed in the chassis call when we reviewed it originally).

Chassisd also uses it for a timing related configuration: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-platform-daemons/blob/master/sonic-chassisd/scripts/chassisd#L312. Probably best to keep it consistent across the different daemons. Imo you should join next weeks chassis call and bring it up for discussion if you feel strongly towards the pmon_daemon_control method.
Thanks Gregory, I will join next week and get more ideas before refactoring this.

@Junchao-Mellanox Can you please help in answering the below question in reference to the PR description?
```
In CmisManagerTask, it calls cmis.set_lpmode for each logical port. The time wait causes a wait_time * num_of_logical_port delay in link up time. The PR is to optimize it.
```

Question
1. From my understanding, the wait time should only apply to the first subport (specifically, the first subport to go through CMIS init for a breakout port group) of a physical port during CMIS initialization. For the remaining subports, the port should already be in high power mode, making the wait effectively a NOOP.
Is the goal of this PR to reduce CMIS initialization time by allowing subsequent logical ports to proceed without waiting for the high power mode transition?

2. Could you also share any performance metrics or stats that demonstrate the improvement from this change?

> @Junchao-Mellanox Can you please help in answering the below question in reference to the PR description?
> 
> ```
> In CmisManagerTask, it calls cmis.set_lpmode for each logical port. The time wait causes a wait_time * num_of_logical_port delay in link up time. The PR is to optimize it.
> ```
>

From my understanding, the wait time should only apply to the first subport (specifically, the first subport to go through CMIS init for a breakout port group) of a physical port during CMIS initialization. For the remaining subports, the port should already be in high power mode, making the wait effectively a NOOP.
>    Is the goal of this PR to reduce CMIS initialization time by allowing subsequent logical ports to proceed without waiting for the high power mode transition?
> 2. Could you also share any performance metrics or stats that demonstrate the improvement from this change?

@mihirpat1 [1]. I think at present set_lpmode() is a busy wait function, which means when you have 8 subports, Cmis Mgr will wait for module to transition from `LpMode` -> `ModuelReady`. This PR is removing this busy wait and making use of `CMIS_STATE_AP_CONF` state where Xcvrd checks for `ModuleReady` in a non-busy way.

@Junchao-Mellanox We need to make sure

1. If module is transitioning from `LpMode` -> `ModuleReady` , and there is a set_lpmod(False) called again(breakout scenario), does that impact the ongoing transition?
2. If there is a timeout for `ModuleReady` , CMIS mgr does `force_cmis_reinit()`, can you confirm if this will eventually help to move the module to `ModuleReady` ?

Hi @mihirpat1 ,

Due my test, set_lpmode takes about 0.5s when there is wait. And it takes about 0.01s when there is no wait. After applying this change, the link up time for 512 ports saves 20 to 30 seconds. You are right about the subport: only the first subport executes the wait. But it still took 64 * 0.5 = ~32 seconds. Also, the idea is that we don't need this wait in set_lpmode function since CmisManagerTask has already done the wait in state machine.

Hi @prgeor ,

For the first question, I suppose it does not matter. If user set module to low power mode during the transitioning from `LpMode` -> `ModuleReady`, the busy wait does not help either. Because set_lpmod(False) could be called right after busy wait succesfully return.

For the second question, my test never hit the timeout for `ModuleReady`. It usually takes no more than 0.5s to reach `ModuleReady`. I think if we reach such timetout, the issue is on module side.

Answer inline to your questions: 1. Why we want to decommission all data paths and try to program with AppSel=0? AK] We can decommission data path lanes by writing AppSel value to 0. We’ve seen configuration failure issues when moving from the default AppSel code (e.g., 1x800G) to the non-default AppSel code (e.g., 2x400G). So, here, since the width of DP lanes changes from 8 to 4 for subport 1, and the remaining 4 are still used by the previous AppSel configuration, the module wouldn’t allow us to change the width of DP lanes. This is when we need to decommission or reset the AppSel of the remaining lanes to 0 and reconfigure to the new AppSel as required. The CMIS spec also recommends this. Check ```6.2.4.3 Host Rules and Recommendations``` 2. When decomissioning all data path it will affect the non-lead ports. what will happens in below case? AK] There’s a known issue with the existing logic: in case of a multi-mode approach (using different Appl for different subports) and speed change. We shouldn’t decommission when the previous lane width matches the current lane width. So, this PR code will decommission when a speed change occurs. We’re working on code changes to optimize this approach. Avoid decommissioning in cases where the width matches and multiple ApplSel configurations are in place. @longhuan-cisco is working on this and there will be separate PR for https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/issues/23006
